Description: Egyptian terracotta model or figure attachment in form of comedy mask. A model of a dramatic mask, an Old Man from the New Comedy with a short beard or, less likely, a Slave. He has a wrinkled brow, heavy eyebrows, large eyeballs and a wide open mouth. Finished along its lower edge, it is broken away elsewhere. Pressed into a one-piece mould, and the mouth cut out; the beard is striated by paring on the outside. A white wash or coating is preserved, over which red and black paint were added and are preserved near the eyes. Light red-brown fabric.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Egyptian Museum, Cairo. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Parallels of locally made actors' masks (British Museum GR1886,0401.1409; Cambridge, Museum of Classical Archaeology NA521; Cambridge, Fitzwilliam Museum GR.18.1887). The fabric on this example is very fine and the detailing on this finer than any of the other locally produced examples. It may have been imported.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.324) (Phase 3)
